location: INOXDINE, Students’ Union Building, Durham Road, Sheffield S10 2TG
title: Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting V
summary: Please join us at our Community Meeting V, on Wednesday March 8th, at Inox Dine with networking lunch. Please note attendance at this event is by invitation only.
body:
Please join us at our Community Meeting V, on Wednesday March 8th, at Inox Dine with networking lunch. Please note attendance at this event is by invitation only.

The meeting will include: an update on the New Centre for Machine Intelligence - a £3.6 million strategic investment by the University of Sheffield; an introduction to the new AI Research Engineering Team, led by Prof Haiping Lu; an update on Shef.AI 2.0; invited talks, community pitches, open-mic, networking opportunities and more! 

There will be additional time 15:30-16:30 for refreshments and informal networking. 

Provisional Agenda

11:45-12:10: Arrival, registration, and networking

12:10-12:30: Network Lead update on the CMI and Shef.AI 2.0 development

12:30-13:30: Networking lunch

13:30-15:30: Invited talks; short pitches; open-mic

15:30-16:30: Tea/coffee refreshments & informal networking

title: Turing Workshop on Open-Source AI Software for Healthcare
summary: Join us at the Turing Workshop on Open-Source AI Software for Healthcare to be held at Enigma, the Alan Turing Institute, with online access via Zoom.
body:
Join us at the Turing Workshop on Open-Source AI Software for Healthcare to be held at Enigma, the Alan Turing Institute, with online access via Zoom.

This workshop aims to bring together research communities interested in this topic to share experiences and discuss recent advances, challenges, and ways forward. The programme will include talks from leading researchers/developers of scikit-learn, Binder, JupyterHub, The Turing Way, MONAI, TorchIO, nilearn, ChemicalX, and DeepReg, as well as a panel discussion on bottlenecks, researcher engagement, and the impact of AI standards. In-person registration has now closed. Registration for online attendance is open until the end of Thursday 17th Nov (GMT).

Register here.

A link for joining remotely will be sent to registrants by email before the workshop.

This event is jointly supported by the Turing Post Doctoral Enrichment Awards (PDEA) and the Turing Interest Group Meta-Learning for Multimodal Data.

title: N8 CIR Machine Learning Theme Launch
summary: Come and join us at the University of Leeds for the launch of our Machine Learning Theme.
body:
Come and join us at the University of Leeds for the launch of our Machine Learning Theme.

Open to all researchers, PGRs and anyone involved in Machine Learning at an N8 institution, this event will bring the Machine Learning community from across N8 together to find out more about N8 CIR, plans for the theme and all-important networking opportunities.

The event will have three key parts:

  • An introduction to N8 CIR and the use of Bede, N8 CIR's high-performance computing platform, for Machine Learning
  • Presentations and posters featuring Machine Learning research from the community (see below)
  • An opportunity for the community to hear about future plans and community building for the theme and to input their thoughts and ideas

Call for Presentation Abstracts

Bayesian Methods in Machine Learning

Machine learning in any area requires data, both for training prediction models and for applying them to solve real-world problems. Bayesian methods are known to be useful to make sense of data, to make better models and to interpret the predictions, especially in the presence of noise in either input data or inference data. With this N8 CIR event, we want to share current practices in using Bayesian methods across a wide range of disciplines and applications, so that this can provide cross-pollination and enrich our understanding of which methods might be applicable.

Submit your 300 word abstract to enquiries@n8cir.org.uk by the 30th of September. Successful presenters will be informed by mid-October.

Call for Posters

Poster submissions are welcome on any aspect of Machine Learning, simply provide a poster title when you register.

Registration is open now and can be found on the N8 CIR website - https://n8cir.org.uk/events/machine-learning-theme-launch/

location: INOXDINE, Students’ Union Building, Durham Road, Sheffield S10 2TG
title: Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting IV
summary: Join us for our fourth Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting, for news and updates from the award lead and interest groups, pitches, panel discussions, networking and much more.
body:
Join us for our fourth Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting, for news and updates from the award lead and interest groups, pitches, panel discussions, networking and much more.

11:30-12:00: Arrival, Coffee/Tea, Registration and Networking

12:00-12:30: Award Lead Update on Turing 2.0 and Sheffield AI Network Development

12:30-13:30: Lunch and Networking [provide your profile on Shef.AI web via QR code!]

13:30-15:00: Pitches, Panel Discussions, Open-mic

Lightning 3 Minute Pitch Presentations (with Q&A) 60-65 mins

Science and Engineering: 15-20 mins

  • David Wagg (MechEng): Digital Twins for Engineering Applications
  • Grant Hill (Chem): Molecules and Materials Update
  • John Oyekan (ACSE): Challenges for Autonomous Learning in Human-Machine Interaction
  • Mark Stevenson (COM): Technology Assisted Review

Social and Humanities: 15-20 mins

  • Jacob Macdonald (UrbanSP): Urban and Mobility Data Science
  • Kate Simpson (DHI): AI and Museum Collections
  • Valeria Vitale (DHI): Beyond Labels: Computational Approaches to Text on Maps
  • Jingxia Wang (UrbanSP): Machine learning for Remote Sensing and Environmental Analysis

Infrastructure and Facilitation: 20-25 mins

  • Ceri Batchelder & Philippa Hedley-Takhar (Team SY): Connecting the Tech Startup Eco-system Across South Yorkshire
  • Twin Karmakharm (COM): AI/ML in the University of Sheffield Research Software Engineering Team
  • Joe Heffer (ITS): IT Support Services, Infrastructure and Consultancy for Machine Learning
  • Gavin Boyce (Library): Library Digital Scholarship Support

Panel Discussion 15mins 

Theme: Growing Shef.AI in the Turing Way

Q1: How to support and accelerate Sheffield’s science & innovation in DS & AI?

Q2. How to grow our people and strengthen our skills to embrace AI opportunities?

Q3. How to engage stakeholders, build our ecosystem, and establish leadership?

Open-mic  10mins 

Your chance to pitch any data science and AI related news, question, opportunity, event etc. that you want to share with the community.

15:00-15:30: Coffee/tea break & networking

15:30-16:30: Breakout activities -2 rounds

Themed Breakout Group Activities and Interest Group Discussions  

Task: Taking the same questions as in the panel discussion and any additional questions you may have, engage in group-brainstorming around focussed themes.

Round 1

A1: AI for Manufacturing [digital twins, materials, chemicals]

A2: AI-enabled Research [understanding (image, sound, sequence...) data; detecting rare events from (astro., health, environ.) data]

A3: Upskilling [training, Decision Making, Management, Local Industry]; Digital Education [curricula, PGR, SCR schools]; Spinouts & Entrepreneurship [linking to investors & VCs]]

A4: IG4b Data-driven Arts/Humanities/Social sciences: roup planning meeting for future IG workshop

 

Round 2

B1: Autonomous Systems/Robotics [systems, safety, security, trustworthiness]

B2: IG4a Urban and Mobility group meeting AND/ Human-centric AI [policy, social, mental, urban, population, legal, ethical]

16:30-17:00 Closing Remarks (Haiping Lu), and Networking.

 

NOTE: When leaving, please leave your badge near the room exit for reuse to reduce waste. Thanks!

title: Deep Gaussian Processes: A Motivation and Introduction
summary: Neil Lawrence “Deep Gaussian Processes: A Motivation and Introduction”
body:
Abstract: Modern machine learning methods have driven significant advances in artificial intelligence, with notable examples coming from Deep Learning, enabling super-human performance in the game of Go and highly accurate prediction of protein folding e.g. AlphaFold. In this talk we look at deep learning from the perspective of Gaussian processes. Deep Gaussian processes extend the notion of deep learning to propagate uncertainty alongside function values. We’ll explain why this is important and show some simple examples.

About the speaker: Neil previously was Professor of machine learning here in Sheffield. He continued to develop applied probabilistic machine learning while director of machine learning at Amazon in Cambridge. Then, in 2019, Neil was appointed as the inaugural DeepMind Professor of Machine Learning at the University of Cambridge.

Mini poster session

If you're working in the field of ML (in particular early careers, or PhD, MSc) we'd be very happy to have your posters up before/after the talk.

Event program
  • 16:30-17:00  Pre-talk drinks/food
  • 17:00-18:00  Talk
  • 18:00-18:30  Drinks/food following talk

To find out more about this event, email us.

location: Design Studio 2, E Floor, Pam Liversidge Building, Corner of Broad Lane and Newcastle Street (entrance on Newcastle Street).
title: Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting III
summary: Join us for our third community meeting in person, 8th June 14:00 to 17:00. The meeting is by invitation and will take place in person at E Floor of Pam Liversidge Building, PLB - Design Studio 2, and virtually.
body:
Join us for our third community meeting in person, 8th June 14:00 to 17:00. The meeting is by invitation and will take place in person at E Floor of Pam Liversidge Building, PLB - Design Studio 2.

All parts of the meeting are hybrid and open to virtual participation.

  • 14:00-14:15  Opening
    • Haiping Lu (COM): Community update
  • 14:15-14:35  Humanities and Social Sciences
    • Caitlin Buck (SoMaS): IG 4b Lead introduction and update
    • Jamie Mclaughlin (DHI): NER Workbench for Cultural Heritage
    • Valeria Vitale (ATI): Machines Reading Maps: from text on maps to linked spatial data
    • IG 4b dialogue with ATI
  • 14:35-14:40  Data-centric Engineering
    • Lindsay Lee (AMRC): Data science in manufacturing - challenges and opportunities
  • 14:40-14:50  Cross-cutting challenges
    • Gavin Boyce (LIBRARY): IG 6f - What makes a visualisation valuable?
    • Maria-Cruz Villa-Uriol (COM): Sequences of temporal data are everywhere - how to effectively explore them?
  • 14:50-15:15  Tea & coffee
  • 15:15-15:35  Science
    • Dan Tovey (Phys & Astron): Lightning classification with the Met Office LEELA network
    • Grant Hill (Chem): IG 3a - Why you should care about new molecules and materials
    • Brooks Paige (ATI/UCL): pitch
    • IG 3a dialogue with ATI
  • 15:35-16:15  Health and Medical Sciences
    • Richard Clayton (COM): IG 1a Intro - Early and accurate detection, diagnosis and treatment of illness(es)
    • Alisha Davies (ATI): pitch
    • IG 1a dialogue with ATI
    • [15:50-16:00] Special session on industry collaboration - focus on South Yorkshire Region and Health
      • Ceri Batchelder (TEAM SY): TEAM SY - connecting the tech ecosystem across South Yorkshire
      • Philippa Hedley-Takhar (P4SY): South Yorkshire P4SY medtech accelerator
    • Mahnaz Arvaneh (ACSE): Closed loop rehabilitation for improving physical and mental health
    • Maria Liakata (ATI/QMUL): pitch
    • IG 1b dialogue with ATI
  • 16:15-16:30  Security, Business, & Public Policy
    • Irini Katsirea (Journalism): IG 5a - How to tackle the systemic risks of online targeting?
    • Maria Liakata (ATI/QMUL): pitch
    • IG 5a Dialogue with ATI
  • 16:30-16:40  Open-Mic: Anyone can be on stage
  • 16:40-16:55  Panel Discussion: AI Infrastructure and Ecosystem
  • 16:55-17:00  Closing

location: INOXDINE, Students’ Union Building, Durham Road, Sheffield S10 2TG [FULLY BOOKED]
title: Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting II
summary: Welcome to the second Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting. Invitations were sent to all who signed up via our previous survey on IGs & Community Meeting II.
body:
Welcome to the second Sheffield Data Science and AI Community Meeting. Invitations were sent to all who signed up via our previous survey on IGs & Community Meeting II.

All parts of the meeting are hybrid and open to Google meets EXCEPT 15:00-15:45
  • 14:00 - 15:00 Turing dialogues and presentations
    • 14:00-14:15: Award Lead update with Q&A
    • 14:15-14:30: Dialogue with ATI: Increasing AI transparency, explainability, interpretability, and energy-efficiency [IG 6b]
    • 14:30-14:45: Dialogue with ATI: Revolutionising data-driven research in the arts, humanities, and social sciences [IG 4b]
    • 14:45-15:00 Five IG pitches
      • Detecting rare events for new insights into the Universe’s fundamentals
      • Best practices for accessible, sustainable, and scalable systems
      • Safe, smart, connected technology (e.g. robotics) and human-machine interaction
      • Studying mobility, active lifestyles, urban environments, and population health
      • Advancing pedagogy and policy to develop education in DS & AI
  • 15:00 - 15:15: Tea & coffee
  • [Multiple sessions–no public Google meets] 15:15 - 15:40 IG parallel breakout discussions
    • Dialogue with ATI [IG 4b]
    • Dialogue with ATI [IG 5b]
    • Within-IG discussions for other IGs
  • 15:45 - 16:15 Group and Individual pitches
    • Research IT Forum
    • Automating/improving data preparation, access, understanding & exploitation
    • Using and analysing data to confidently infer causal relationships
    • Tracking insects in the wild
    • Machine vision for human machine interaction
    • Text mining from diverse natural language sources
    • Knowledge-aware machine learning: An accessible software for multiple data sources
    • Visualisation for sense-making
    • Emulation-based uncertainty quantification methodology: Building energy simulation use case
  • 16:15-17:00 Final Turing dialogues
    • 16:15-16:30: Dialogue with ATI: Effective and efficient information visualisation to various audiences [IG 6f]
    • 16.30-16:55: Dialogue with ATI: Identifying and tackling mis- and disinformation & enhancing privacy/security [IG 5a]
    • 16.55-17:00: Closing
  • 17:00-17:30 Socialising
